{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Javier González Fraga |image = Javier González Fraga.jpg |imagesize = 170px |office = [[List of presidents of the Central Bank of Argentina|President of the Central Bank of Argentina]] |term_start = June 13, 1990 |term_end = January 29, 1991 |president = [[Carlos Menem]] |predecessor = [[Antonio Erman González]] |successor = [[Roque Fernández]] |office2 = President of the Central Bank of Argentina |term_start2 = July 8, 1989 |term_end2 = November 24, 1989 |president2 = [[Carlos Menem]] |predecessor2 = [[Enrique García Vázquez]] |successor2 = Egidio Iannella |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1948|5|12}} |birth_place = [[Buenos Aires]], Argentina |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Argentine]] |alma_mater = [[Pontifical Catholic University of Argentina]] |signature = Firma González Fraga.png }}
'''Javier González Fraga''' (born May 12, 1948) is an Argentine economist and businessman. He served as President of the [[Central Bank of Argentina]] from 1989 to 1991, and was nominated as running-mate by [[Ricardo Alfonsín]] for his [[Argentine general election, 2011|2011 campaign]] for the Presidency.
==Life and times== González Fraga was born in [[Buenos Aires]] as the youngest of four children to Elvira Fraga and N. González Casartelli.<ref name=alcurnia>{{cite web|url=http://www.genealogiafamiliar.net/getperson.php?personID=I19994&tree=BVCZ|title=Javier González Fraga|publisher=Genealogía Familiar}}</ref> He earned a degree in [[Economics]] with honors at the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Argentina]],<ref name=konex>{{cite web|url=http://www.fundacionkonex.org/b1184-javier_a_gonzalez_fraga|title=Javier A. González Fraga|publisher=Fundación Konex}}</ref> and in 1974, was brought on by ''[[La Nación]]'', one of the nation's leading news dailies, as a financial columnist.<ref name=idea>{{cite web|url=http://www.ideared.org/coloquio39/expositores/gonzalez_fraga.asp|title=Javier González Fraga. Curriculum vitae|publisher=Idea}}</ref> He later earned a fellowship at the [[Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs]] at [[Harvard University]], and at the [[London School of Economics]].<ref name=konex/> He married Bárbara Morea Giménez, and had two children; they later separated.<ref name=alcurnia/>
He established a [[dairy farm]], ''La Salamandra'', near [[Luján, Buenos Aires]], in 1979,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infoemprendedores.com.ar/info/leeremprendedor.asp?id=284 |title=Granja La Salamandra |publisher=''Info Emprendedores'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070305142216/http://www.infoemprendedores.com.ar/info/leeremprendedor.asp?id=284 |archivedate=2007-03-05 |df= }}</ref> and continued to write on finance and economics, authoring ''El Mercado de Capitales'' (1982) and ''El Sistema Financiero'' (1980 and 1985).<ref name=idea/> He served as adviser to the [[State enterprise]] bureau during the [[Raúl Alfonsín]] Administration, and was hired by [[Bank of Credit and Commerce International|BCCI]] principal [[Ghaith Pharaon]] to manage [[Swap (finance)|debt-equity swaps]] for the bank, as well as [[portfolio investment]]s that included the [[Four Seasons Hotel Buenos Aires|Park Hyatt Buenos Aires]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiempo.elargentino.com/notas/javier-gonzalez-fraga-de-alfonsin-pharaon-de-pharaon-alfonsin|title= Javier González Fraga: de Alfonsín a Pharaon, de Pharaon a Alfonsín|publisher=''Tiempo Argentino''}}</ref>
===Tenure at the Central Bank=== The election of [[Justicialist Party]] candidate [[Carlos Menem]] in [[Argentine general election, 1989|1989]], and his reliance on the [[agribusiness]] conglomerate [[Bunge & Born]] for economic policy during the presidential transition, gave the company's [[Chief Operating Officer]], Orlando Ferreres, the power to choose most of the new administration's economic team. He recommended the relatively young González Fraga, who was well-known to the local banking sector as a policy consultant, to be the new President of the [[Central Bank of Argentina|Central Bank]].<ref name=cl625>''Clarín''. Síntesis de la semana. June 25, 1989.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/07/business/international-report-inflation-unites-peronists-and-argentine-business.html?pagewanted=all|title=Inflation Unites Peronists and Argentine Business|publisher=''The New York Times'' | first=Shirley|last=Christian|date=August 7, 1989}}</ref> The nominee informed the President-elect that he had not voted for him (harboring policy differences, as well, with Bunge & Born personnel);<ref name=lp>{{cite web|url=http://www.laprensa.com.ar/Note.aspx?Note=358932|title=Economía, memorias del fuego|publisher=''La Prensa''}}</ref> González Fraga, nevertheless, was sworn in with the new administration on July 8.
González Fraga leveraged business confidence in the new economic team to stabilize the highly undervalued [[Argentine austral|austral]], and despite favoring greater [[exchange rate flexibility]] in light of the critical need for [[foreign exchange reserves]] (which had declined to around us$120 million, with us$4.5 billion in [[arrears]]),<ref name=cl625/> González Fraga eliminated [[trade finance]] lines of credit and increased [[U.S. dollar]] purchases from exporters. These measures created friction with both the agricultural sector and Bunge & Born itself, though he continued to enjoy Menem's support.<ref name=lp/>
The austral, which had fallen sharply (from 450 to 650 per dollar) in the days prior to Menem's July 8 inaugural in anticipation of a [[devaluation]], stabilized. The [[1989 riots in Argentina|financial crisis]] continued to exert pressure on prices, however, and monthly inflation reached 197% in July. The [[Argentine mint|National Mint]] could not meet demand for banknotes, and in response, the new Central Bank President ordered the mint to triple production by printing higher denominations on old (circa-1980) [[Peso ley]] templates, and issuing bills printed on only one side. The crisis subsided in August, and by September, monthly inflation was in single digits. González Fraga, however, remained in strained terms with the Bunge & Born-dominated Economy Ministry, and sought as much independence for the Central Bank as possible.<ref name=lp/> Ultimately, however, Economy Minister [[Néstor Rapanelli]]'s opposition to González Fraga's call for a [[floating exchange rate]] led the central banker to resign on November 24.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/24/business/argentine-bank-head-quits.html?scp=1&sq=%22Javier+Gonzalez+Fraga%22&st=nyt|title=Argentine Bank Head Quits|publisher=''The New York Times'' | date=November 24, 1989}}</ref> These news added to concerns that the us$2 billion in new [[portfolio investment]] envisaged in July failed to materialize,<ref name=lp/> and amid a new currency crisis, Rapanelli himself resigned three weeks later.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/18/business/international-report-ministry-shift-in-argentina.html|title=Ministry shift in Argentina|publisher=''The New York Times'' | date=December 18, 1989}}</ref>
Menem loyalist Antonio Erman González was named President of the Central Bank in March 1990, and González Fraga returned to the institution as its Vice President. A reversal of the roles each had in 1989, this partnership continued when in June, he succeeded Erman González, while the latter retained the Economy Ministry. Even as the nation's finances stabilized, his agenda in the ensuing months was topped by difficult repayment negotiations over mounting foreign debt arrears (which had reached us$6 billion by then),<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/10/business/argentina-to-get-aid-and-begin-debt-talks.html|title=Argentina to Get Aid and Begin Debt Talks|publisher=''The New York Times'' | first=Jonathan|last=Fuerbringer|date=May 10, 1990}}</ref> as well as by ongoing investigations into [[securities fraud]] allegedly committed against the Central Bank by numerous institutions during the crisis.<ref>Quintela, Roberto. ''Crisis bancarias y corrupción''. Buenos Aires: Editorial Dunken, 2005.</ref> Revelations in January 1991 that Menem Administration officials had solicited [[bribe]]s from beef processor [[Swift & Company]], as well as a renewed currency crisis, led to the resignation of the entire economic team.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/01/29/business/bank-holiday-in-argentina-as-currency-plunges-12.5.html?scp=2&sq=%22Javier+Gonzalez+Fraga%22&st=nyt|title=Bank Holiday in Argentina As Currency Plunges 12.5%|publisher=''The New York Times'' | date=January 29, 1991}}</ref>
===Later life=== [[File:Alfonsín, González Fraga, Gil Lavedra y Bazze.jpg|thumb|240px|González Fraga in a conversation with (''from left'') Congressman [[Ricardo Gil Lavedra]], UCR presidential candidate [[Ricardo Alfonsín]], and Miguel Bazze of the Buenos Aires Province UCR during the [[Argentine general election, 2011|2011 elections]].]] González Fraga returned to the private sector. He was named Director of the Argentine Institute of Capital Markets, a [[think tank]] associated with the [[Buenos Aires Stock Exchange]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iamc.sba.com.ar/ |title=Instituto Argentino de Mercado de Capitales}}</ref> and was later named Vice President of the Stock Exchange.<ref name=konex/> He remained active as a dairy farmer. He established a manufacturing plant at [http://www.lasalamandra.com.ar/ La Salamandra] in 1991, and introduced [[buffalo mozzarella]] to Argentina;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/203163-en-la-granja-la-salamandra-las-bufalas-son-buenas-anfitrionas|title=En la granja La Salamandra las búfalas son buenas anfitrionas|publisher=''La Nación''}}</ref> La Salamandra's [[dulce de leche]], a traditional Argentine confection, earned first place at the 2000 [[NASFT|Fancy Food Show of New York]].<ref name=idea/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snazzygourmet.com/La_Salamandra_Dulce_de_Leche_p/ls-100.htm |title=La Salamandra Dulce de Leche |publisher=Snazzy Gourmet |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324233450/http://www.snazzygourmet.com/La_Salamandra_Dulce_de_Leche_p/ls-100.htm |archivedate=2012-03-24 |df= }}</ref>
He also returned to academia, and was given tenure as Professor of Economics at his alma mater in 1994.<ref name=idea/> He earned a [[Konex Award]] for his role as an entrepreneur in 1998, and in 2004, was offered the post of Director of the National Arts Fund by President [[Néstor Kirchner]]; personal differences with actress [[Nacha Guevara]], a key Kirchner supporter, stymied the appointment, however.<ref name=uno>{{cite web|url=http://www.unoreconquista.com/reconquista/El-economista-Javier-Gonzalez-Fraga-sera-el-candidato-a-vicepresidente-de-Alfonsin-20110603-0006.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324233448/http://www.unoreconquista.com/reconquista/El-economista-Javier-Gonzalez-Fraga-sera-el-candidato-a-vicepresidente-de-Alfonsin-20110603-0006.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-03-24 |title=El economista Javier González Fraga será el candidato a vicepresidente de Alfonsín |publisher=''Diario Uno'' }}</ref> González Fraga became known as one of the nation's foremost experts and proponents of [[Keynesian economics]].<ref name=cl07>{{cite web|url=http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2007/02/15/elpais/p-01001.htm|title=Javier González Fraga: "De Keynes, Kirchner sólo tiene la 'K' del apellido"|publisher=''Clarín''}}</ref> He would influence a number of future policy makers in Argentina, including [[Martín Lousteau]], with whom he wrote ''Sin Atajos'' (''"Without Shortcuts"'')<ref>{{cite book|author1=Javier González Fraga|author2=Martín Lousteau|title=Sin atajos: de la ciclotimia a la madurez del desarrollo|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2MRDAAAAYAAJ|year=2005|publisher=Temas Grupo Editorial|isbn=978-950-9445-12-3}}</ref> in 2005,<ref name=uno/> and [[Débora Giorgi]], who worked with González Fraga during his tenure at the Central Bank.<ref name=u24>{{cite web|url=http://www.urgente24.com/noticias/val/9343/lavagna-senalo-a-gonzalez-fraga-un-vice-para-alfonsin-pensando-en-la-economia-.html |title=Lavagna señaló a González Fraga, un vice para Alfonsín pensando en la economía |publisher=''Urgente 24'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929075828/http://www.urgente24.com/noticias/val/9343/lavagna-senalo-a-gonzalez-fraga-un-vice-para-alfonsin-pensando-en-la-economia-.html |archivedate=2011-09-29 |df= }}</ref> He himself, however, never garnered an appointment to the powerful Economy Ministry, despite having been frequently considered for the post.<ref name=cl07/>
Close to important figures in both the center-left [[Radical Civic Union|UCR]] and the center-right [[Federal Peronism]], González Fraga was entrusted by UCR presidential nominee [[Ricardo Alfonsín]] to offer former Economy Minister [[Roberto Lavagna]] the vice-presidential slot for the [[Argentine general election, 2011|2011 elections]]; Lavagna reportedly instead persuaded González Fraga to run with Alfonsín, and on June 2, their UCR ticket was formally announced.<ref name=u24/> They placed third with 11% of the vote.

{{Portuguese name|Rodrigues|Berardo}} {{Infobox person |name = Joe Berardo | honorific_suffix =[[Order of Prince Henry|GCIH]], [[Order of Prince Henry|ComIH]] |image = Joe berardo.jpg |image_size = 225px |caption = |birth_name = José Manuel Rodrigues Berardo |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Santa Luzia (Funchal)|Santa Luzia]], [[Madeira]], Portugal |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = [[Portugal|Portuguese]] |other_names = |known_for = |education = |employer = |occupation = [[Businessman]], [[stock investor]], [[speculator]], and [[art collector]] |title = |salary = |networth = €598 million |height = |weight = |boards = |religion = |spouse = Carolina da Conceição Gonçalves {{small|(1969–present)}} | children = Renato Gonçalves Berardo
Cláudia Gonçalves Berardo |mother = Ana Rodrigues |father = Manuel Berardo Gomes |relatives = [[Ilse Everlien Berardo]] {{small|(Sister-in-law)}}
[[Rubina Berardo]] {{small|(Niece)}} |signature = |website = |footnotes = }} '''José Manuel Rodrigues Berardo''', [[Order of Prince Henry|GCIH]], [[Order of Prince Henry|ComIH]], best known as '''Joe Berardo''', is a Portuguese [[businessman]], [[stock investor]], [[speculator]], and [[art collector]]. According to Portuguese magazine ''[[Exame (Portuguese magazine)|Exame]]'', he had an estimated net worth of €598 million in 2010, making him one of the wealthiest people in Portugal.[http://aeiou.expresso.pt/americo-amorim-e-o-mais-rico-de-portugal=f596561 Top ten richest people in Portugal] in Exame {{pt icon}} ==Life== Berardo was born at Santa Luzia, [[Funchal]], [[Madeira]], Portugal. Berardo left school when he was 13 years old and got a low-ranked job in the winery sector of [[Madeira wine]]. At the age of 18, he emigrated to [[South Africa]] where he worked in horticulture distribution and eventually set up large commercial ventures, becoming at the end of the 20th century one of the most renowned and wealthiest Portuguese [[entrepreneur]]s. In South Africa, he created [[Egoli Consolidated Mines Ltd]], a [[gold extraction]] company. Initially, the gold extraction was performed using low-value waste lands that were apparently being ignored. Later, the mining company started to deal with [[diamond]] mining as well. Berardo returned to Portugal in 1986.[https://diarioeconomico.sapo.pt/edicion/diarioeconomico/nacional/economia/pt/desarrollo/1006881.html Biography of José Berardo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703084518/http://diarioeconomico.sapo.pt/edicion/diarioeconomico/nacional/economia/pt/desarrollo/1006881.html |date=2007-07-03 }}, in Diário Económico {{pt icon}} ==Stock market== As a very wealthy and active [[stock trader]], Berardo is a central personality on the Portuguese stock exchange, [[Euronext Lisbon]], where he trades large amounts of stock throughout the year, often having immediate [[capital gain]] as his only perceived goal. His businesses include [[hotels]], [[tobacco]], animal food, [[telecommunications]], [[banking]], and [[wine]]s. Berardo's estimated total wealth, including stock in large Portuguese banking and telecommunications companies, is over €1.9 billion. ===Long-term stockholding=== Berardo also has long-term investments in large companies, like [[Millennium BCP]] bank and [[Portugal Telecom]] (PT) telecommunications operator, which are both listed on the Euronext Lisbon. In 2006, he took a prominent part in the struggle against [[Sonae.com]]'s very publicized takeover bid over Portugal Telecom. Sonae.com's takeover bid opposing [[Belmiro de Azevedo]] (founder and historical chairman of [[Sonae]] holding company) and his son Paulo Azevedo (ex-head officer of [[Sonae.com]] telecommunications operator and actual chairman of [[Sonae]]) to the investor Berardo and PT's administrators [[Zeinal Bava]] and Henrique Granadeiro, failed. ===S.L. Benfica - Futebol, S.A.D. share bid=== In June 2007, Berardo made a bid for 60% of [[S.L. Benfica|Sport Lisboa e Benfica]] - Futebol, [[Sociedade Anónima Desportiva|S.A.D.]]'s shares at €3.50 a share,{{cite news|last=Duarte|first=Pedro|date=15 June 2007|title=Joe Berardo lança OPA para controlar Benfica|trans-title=Joe Berardo launches takeover bid to control Benfica|url=https://economico.sapo.pt/edicion/diarioeconomico/nacional/empresas/pt/desarrollo/1006204.html|dead-url=yes|language=Portuguese|newspaper=Diário Económico|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602112814/http://economico.sapo.pt/edicion/diarioeconomico/nacional/empresas/pt/desarrollo/1006204.html|archive-date=2 June 2013|access-date=2 July 2015}}{{cite news|last=Duarte|first=Pedro|date=15 June 2013|title=OPA incide sobre 60% do capital da SAD do Benfica|trans-title=Takeover bid focuses on 60% of Benfica SAD's capital|url=https://economico.sapo.pt/edicion/diarioeconomico/nacional/empresas/pt/desarrollo/1006165.html|dead-url=yes|language=Portuguese|newspaper=Diário Económico|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225184515/http://economico.sapo.pt/edicion/diarioeconomico/nacional/empresas/pt/desarrollo/1006165.html|archive-date=25 December 2013|access-date=2 July 2015}} a 30% premium to the recent share price. But the price was well below the €5 a share set at Benfica's [[Initial public offering|IPO]] in May 2007, when after an initial flurry of optimism the shares fell steadily to below €3 apiece, hammered hard by the team's fourth-place finish in the [[Portuguese Liga]] and the failure to make any great gains in [[UEFA Champions League|European competition]]. Berardo's bid was not hostile, as reports said the Benfica management had been informed in advance and was generally in favor of the offer. Overall, the bid was worth some €31.5 million and was conditional on Berardo netting 50% of the company plus one share, to ensure control. The bid valued S.L. Benfica - Futebol, S.A.D. at €52.5 million. However, Berardo did not exclude a major stake in the Futebol, S.A.D., which could have been achieved within the 33% [[free float]] of publicly traded stock that was issued in the stock market in May 2007. Berardo, who is a paying member of S.L. Benfica (''sócio'') and a declared [[Supporters of S.L. Benfica|supporter of the club]], failed to become the largest individual stockholder in the club's S.A.D., since only about 1% of the intended stock was sold to him as of the 20 August 2007 deadline. ==Club Sport Marítimo== After his failed attempt to bid on Benfica, Berardo refocused his attention on his hometown club [[C.S. Marítimo|Club Sport Marítimo]], of which has also declared his support for and is a registered member also. On 17 November 2007, during the club's 97th anniversary celebration, he was honoured with a silver medal to commemorate his 25 years as a Marítimo member.[http://www.record.pt/noticia.asp?id=765029&idCanal=20 ''Berardo vai receber medalha de 25 anos de sócio''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071118014326/http://www.record.pt/noticia.asp?id=765029&idCanal=20 |date=2007-11-18 }}, article in Jornal Record, November 17, 2007 {{pt icon}} He used the occasion to announce his interest in the clubs' new stadium plans, the [[Estádio do Marítimo]], and offer his aid as a "supporter with passion" for the club.[http://www.record.pt/noticia.asp?id=765241&idCanal=20 ''Berardo quer ajudar''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071120141703/http://www.record.pt/noticia.asp?id=765241&idCanal=20 |date=2007-11-20 }}, article in Jornal Record, November 19, 2007 {{pt icon}} ==Art collection== Berardo has a special interest for [[modern art]], being one of the most successful contemporary [[art collector]]s in Portugal. An inveterate collector, he started as a schoolboy with stamps, postcards and matchboxes and graduated to modern and contemporary art in the 1980s. His various collections, which include art deco and Chinese porcelain, encompass more than 40,000 works, of which some 1,200 are by well-known modern and contemporary artists with a reported value of $750 million. Much of his art collection has in the past been used as collateral to borrow from banks.Colin Gleadel (September 13, 2010), [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/artsales/8000553/Jose-Berardo-interview-for-Vilamoura-sculpture-park-in-the-Algarve.html# Jose Berardo interview for Vilamoura sculpture park in the Algarve] ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Berardo went public with his collection in 1997, displaying works at an old casino in Sintra, and then at the white stone fortress-like [[Centro Cultural de Belém]], in [[Lisbon]]. By agreement with the [[Portuguese Government]], a [[foundation (charity)|foundation]] (''Fundação de Arte Moderna e Contemporânea—Colecção Berardo'') was created to support the housing of his art collection of roughly 1,800 worksSeth Sherwood (February 18, 2011), [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/19/arts/19iht-sclisbon19.html In Lisbon, Sowing the Seeds of Culture] ''[[New York Times]]''. at the Centro Cultural de Belém.{{cite web|url=http://www.dre.pt/gratis/diplomas/diplomas1s.asp |title=The foundation was created by Decree-Law 164/2006 of 9 August |accessdate=2010-10-27 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011010622/http://www.dre.pt/gratis/diplomas/diplomas1s.asp |archivedate=October 11, 2007 |df= }} (from the Ministry of Culture) accessible from the search engine for the ''[[Diário da República]]'', the Portuguese Government's official gazette. {{pt icon}} Much as the Spanish state did with the [[Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum]] in Madrid, the government agreed to house part of his collection and took a 10-year option to buy 862 paintings and sculptures for 316 million euros, based on a [[Christie's]] valuation in 2006.Vernon Silver and Anabela Reis (February 3, 2010), [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aIxF2nwtfmxE Billionaire Whistle-Blower Loses $730 Million Alleging Fraud] ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. The [[Museu Colecção Berardo]] was inaugurated on June 25, 2007. Berardo's 35-hectare sculpture park in Quinta dos Loridos, north of Lisbon, opened in phases since 2006.Gareth Harris (January 1, 2013), [http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/Portuguese-billionaire-adds-works-inspired-by-Bamiyan-Buddhas-to-his-vast-sculpture-park/28289 Portuguese billionaire adds works inspired by Bamiyan Buddhas to his vast sculpture park] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115025853/http://theartnewspaper.com/articles/Portuguese-billionaire-adds-works-inspired-by-Bamiyan-Buddhas-to-his-vast-sculpture-park/28289 |date=2013-01-15 }} ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''. When he read about the [[Taliban]]’s destruction of Afghanistan’s enormous stone Buddhas in [[Bamiyan]] in 2001, he bought a massive range of Buddhist statues, and created the ''Buddha Eden Gardens'' (about 45 minutes outside of Lisbon). In 2011, Berardo set up the ''Aliança Underground Museum'', a free exhibition of tiles, ethnographic art, ceramics, minerals and fossils in an unused tunnel on a winemaker’s property in [[Sangalhos]]. In 2012, an exhibition of works from Berardo's Modern and contemporary collection, including pieces by [[Gerhard Richter]], [[Francis Bacon]] and [[Andy Warhol]], was on show at the Gary Nader Art Centre in Miami, Florida.Gareth Harris (December 8, 2012), [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Miami-Beach-could-get-even-more-Art-Deco/28246 Miami Beach could get even more Art Deco] ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''. ==Honours and Awards== === National Honours === *[[File:PRT Order of Prince Henry - Commander BAR.png|80px]] Commander of the [[Order of Prince Henry]], [[Portugal]] (13 March 1985){{cite web|title=Cidadãos Nacionais Agraciados com Ordens Portuguesas|url=http://www.ordens.presidencia.pt/?idc=153|website=Página Oficial das Ordens Honoríficas Portuguesas|accessdate=31 July 2016}} *[[File:PRT Order of Prince Henry - Grand Cross BAR.png|80px]] Grand-Cross of the [[Order of Prince Henry]], [[Portugal]] (4 October 2004) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Berardo, Joe}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Funchal]] [[Category:Madeiran businesspeople]] [[Category:Portuguese businesspeople]] [[Category:Portuguese billionaires]] [[Category:Portuguese philanthropists]] [[Category:Portuguese stock traders]] [[Category:Museum founders]] [[Category:20th-century art collectors]] [[Category:21st-century art collectors]] [[Category:20th-century Portuguese businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century Portuguese businesspeople]]

{{Infobox person | name = John Robert Beyster | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = July 26, 1924 | birth_place = [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2014|12|22|1924|7|26}} | death_place = [[La Jolla]], [[California]] | alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]] | occupation = Scientist, entrepreneur | main interests = | spouse = Betty Beyster | website = http://www.beyster.com/ }} '''John Robert Beyster''' (July 26, 1924 – December 22, 2014), often styled '''J. Robert Beyster''', was the founder of [[Science Applications International Corporation]].<ref>Dr. J. Robert Beyster with [[Peter Economy]], The SAIC Solution: How We Built an $8 Billion Employee-Owned Technology Company, John Wiley & Sons (2007) p.xiii</ref> He was Chairman of the Board until his retirement in July 2004,<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/24/business/j-robert-beyster-scientist-and-entrepreneur-is-dead-at-90.html?_r=0</ref> and also served as Chief Executive Officer (CEO) until November 2003. A recognized authority on [[national security]] and [[nuclear reactor physics]], Beyster committed 35 years of his life to building SAIC on the founding tenets of [[employee ownership]] and technical excellence. In recent years, he extended this commitment to the American business community by founding two nonprofit organizations to assist organizations considering employee ownership—the [[Beyster Institute]] and the Foundation for Enterprise Development.
Beyster was born in [[Detroit, Michigan]], in 1924,<ref>http://www.xconomy.com/san-diego/2014/12/23/saic-founder-j-robert-beyster-dies/?single_page=true</ref> and grew up in [[Grosse Ile, Michigan]]. He attended school at Slocum Truax High School in [[Trenton, Michigan]], and was [[salutatorian]] of his graduating class. As he was preparing to graduate from high school, the United States entered [[World War II]], and he enlisted in the [[U.S. Navy]]. He was sent to college at the [[University of Michigan]], where he was enrolled in the [[V-12 Navy College Training Program|V12 Officer Training Program]]. He was commissioned as an ensign, and eventually served on a destroyer based in [[Norfolk, Virginia]] before leaving the service six months later.<ref>http://www.sailingscuttlebutt.com/2014/12/22/eight-bells-dr-j-robert-beyster/</ref> Educated at the [[University of Michigan]] (COE: BSE, MS, PhD),<ref>http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/dec/22/beyster-saic-dies/</ref> Beyster worked as a scientist for [[Westinghouse Electric Corporation|Westinghouse]] Atomic Power Division on the company’s nuclear submarine program in the 1950s.<ref>http://www.federalnewsradio.com/130/3768420/SAIC-Leidos-founder-dead-at-90</ref> He soon followed many of his college associates to [[New Mexico]] to work as a research [[physics|physicist]] at the [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]].<ref>http://www.sddt.com/News/article.cfm?SourceCode=20141223cza&_t=SAIC+founder+J+Robert+Beyster+dies+at+age+90#.VJms1sDhA</ref> In 1957 he became the chairman of the Accelerator Physics Department of [[General Atomics]] where he remained until it was bought by [[Gulf Oil]] in 1968.<ref>https://www.leidos.com/feature/the-solutions-man</ref>
In 1969, Beyster raised money to start Science Applications, Inc. (SAI) by investing the proceeds from selling stock he had received from General Atomic, combined with funds raised from the early employees who bought stock in the young enterprise.<ref>http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/dec/22/beyster-saic-dies/</ref> The company was renamed Science Applications International Corporation (SAIC) as it expanded its operations. Initially the company’s focus was on projects for the U.S. government related to nuclear power and weapons effects study programs. Contrary to traditional business models, Beyster designed SAIC so that ownership of the company and profits belonged to the company’s employees. This shared ownership was accompanied by shared responsibility and freedom in business development. SAIC attracted and retained highly educated (most with PhDs or master's degrees) and motivated entrepreneurs that helped the company to grow and diversify. Today, SAIC, now named [[Leidos]], performs projects for commercial and government customers related to information technology, systems integration and eSolutions, national and homeland security, energy, the environment, space, telecommunications, health care, and logistics. When Beyster retired as Chairman of SAIC on July 16, 2004, the company had annual revenues of $6.7 billion and more than 43,000 employees.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/24/business/j-robert-beyster-scientist-and-entrepreneur-is-dead-at-90.html?_r=0</ref>
Beyster founded the Foundation for Enterprise Development in 1986<ref>https://www.leidos.com/feature/the-solutions-man</ref> "to help develop successful enterprises in the U.S. and around the world" by focusing on "advancing entrepreneurship and employee ownership through its work with technologists, entrepreneurs, executives, governments, and educators." In 2004, the Foundation launched the [[Beyster Institute]], which is "dedicated to training, education, and consulting in employee ownership and entrepreneurship."<ref>https://www.leidos.com/feature/the-solutions-man</ref>
Beyster wrote or co-authored approximately 60 publications and reports, as well as the books, The SAIC Solution: How We Built an $8 Billion Employee-Owned Technology Company, published by [[John Wiley & Sons]] in 2007<ref>{{cite news|last1=Glass|first1=jon w.|title=SAIC creator's book touts employee ownership|url=http://hamptonroads.com/node/245611|accessdate=27 November 2014|agency=The Virginian-Pilot|date=April 3, 2007|quote=Beyster, 82, retired as SAIC's chairman in July 2004. A nuclear physicist by training and a self-described "evangelist" for employee-owned companies, Beyster said he wrote the book to provide entrepreneurs and business executives a model. He wrote it with Peter Economy, an author or co-author of more than 75 business books.}}</ref> and Names, Numbers, and Network Solutions: The Monetization of the Internet, cowritten with Michael A. Daniels and published in 2013. A fellow of the [[American Nuclear Society]], Beyster has served as Chairman of its Reactor Physics Division and Shielding Division. He was a fellow of the [[American Physical Society]], a member of the Scientific Advisory Group to the Director, Strategic Target Planning Staff of the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]], and a member of the [[National Academy of Engineering]]. He also served as Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Directors of the [[University of California, San Diego]] Foundation.<ref>https://www.leidos.com/feature/the-solutions-man</ref>
[[Defense Advanced Research Project Agency]] designated Beyster an Honorary Program Manager for his distinguished contributions to the agency over his career. He also received the Engineering Manager of the Year Award in 2000 from the American Society of Engineering Management, the 2001 Spirit of San Diego Award from the San Diego Regional Chamber of Commerce, the Lifetime Achievement Award from [[Ernst & Young]] in 2003, and the “Supporter of Entrepreneurialism” award from Arthur Young and Venture magazine — at their Entrepreneur of the Year awards ceremony — for his efforts to support and promote entrepreneurship.<ref>https://www.leidos.com/feature/the-solutions-man</ref>
In 2006, the San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation (EDC) recognized Beyster with the Herb Klein Civic Leadership Award for his outstanding leadership in addressing regional challenges through collaboration with public, private, and civic partners. Beyster is the recipient of a lifetime achievement award from the University of California, San Diego’s CONNECT program for providing 25 years of outstanding service to the community. The [[Horatio Alger Association for Distinguished Americans]] selected Beyster to be a 2008 Horatio Alger Award recipient. This honor is bestowed upon those individuals who have overcome adversity to achieve great successes through the American free enterprise system.<ref>https://www.leidos.com/feature/the-solutions-man</ref>
A former naval man, Beyster enjoyed sailing and was the owner of ''Solutions'', a Hinckley motor yacht. While Beyster was still at SAIC, the company backed and provided critical design technology to a number of U.S entries in the [[America's Cup]] race.<ref>http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/dec/22/beyster-saic-dies/</ref>
On Wednesday, April 11, 2012, the computer science engineering building at the University of Michigan was rededicated in his name as the Bob and Betty Beyster Building. Bob and Betty Beyster married at St. Alban’s Church in Austin, Texas in 1955 and have three adult children.<ref>http://www.beyster.com/blog/?p=174</ref>
In 2008, Beyster was inducted into the [[International Air & Space Hall of Fame]] at the [[San Diego Air & Space Museum]].<ref>Sprekelmeyer, Linda, editor. ''These We Honor: The International Aerospace Hall of Fame''. Donning Co. Publishers, 2006. {{ISBN|978-1-57864-397-4}}.</ref>
Beyster died at his home in La Jolla, California on December 22, 2014.<ref>http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/dec/22/beyster-saic-dies/</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} '''Juliusz Karol Kunitzer''' ({{lang-de|Julius Kunitzer}}) (1843–1905) was a [[Poland|Polish]]-German industrialist, economic activist, philanthropist, one of the industrial magnates of [[Łódź]] ([[Congress Poland]]/[[Vistula Land]]). He owned a textile and later a joint stock company. His viciousness towards workers and cooperation with Russian authorities gained him notoriety among Łódż citizens. He was assassinated by [[Polish Socialist Party]] activists in the aftermath of the [[Łódź insurrection (1905)|1905 Łódź insurrection]].
Kunitzer was a polarizing personality and career. Known among Łódź's elites as a shrewd businessman, "cotton king" who became a tycoon due to his personal skills and luck, respected for this and his philanthropy and other public initiatives, for others – particularly radicals and socialists, he was a vicious exploiter of workers and a leader of anti-labor industrialists.<ref name=dl>{{pl icon}} ''[http://www.dzienniklodzki.pl/panorama/49211,kunitzer-krol-widzewa,id,t.html?cookie=1 Kunitzer – król Widzewa]'', Dziennik Łódzki, 26 September 2008</ref>
==Biography== [[File:Bronisław Wilkoszewski – Pałac J. Kunitzera.jpg|thumb|Kunitzer's villa, ul. Spacerowa 15, Łódź]] Kunitzer was born on 19 September 1843 in the [[Przedbórz|Pohulanka]] village, in Russian-controlled [[Congress Poland]] (increasingly known as the [[Vistula Land]]).<ref name=lodzapgov>{{pl icon}} [http://www.lodz.ap.gov.pl/fab6.html JULIUSZ KAROL KUNITZER]</ref> His family had roots in German burgher society, and moved to the Polish territories in the 1830s<ref name=lodzapgov/> Kunitzer described himself as a Pole, including during a public speech to Russian businessmen in [[Nizhny Novgorod]] which caused a brief sensation.<ref>Polacy-Niemcy-Żydzi w Łodzi w XIX-XX w:sąsiedzi dalecy i bliscy Paweł Samuś,page 224 1997</ref><ref>Ilustrowana encyklopedia historii łodzi, Urząd Miasta Łodzi, nr IV / 1, page 198 [http://www.uml.lodz.pl/get.php?id=835]</ref> His father, Jakub, a [[weaver (occupation)|weaver]] by profession, died in 1850, after which Juliusz with his mother moved to [[Tyniec]].<ref name=lodzapgov/> Young Kunitzer became a weaver, following his father's footsteps.<ref name=lodzapgov/>
He came to [[Łódź]] in 1855.<ref name=lodzapgov/> He joined the E. Hentschl's factory, quickly advancing to a managerial position.<ref name=lodzapgov/> In 1869 he married Agnieszka Meyer, sister of the industrialist [[Ludwik Meyer]].<ref name=lodzapgov/> Using his wife's [[dowry]], he invested in a construction of a new factory, which begun operations in the following year.<ref name=lodzapgov/> In partnership with Ludwik Meyer, in 1874, he bought the Hentschl's factory, damaged by the fire, and operated the "Kunitzer i Meyer" company.<ref name=lodzapgov/> In 1879 he withdrew from that partnership, built cotton industry in the village of [[Widzew]] near Łódź, and begun a different one with [[Theodor Julius Heinzel]].<ref name=lodzapgov/> Over the next few decades his factory complex expanded, with a dedicated railway line, worker's housing (150 homes), a hospital, a school, church, shops, and other buildings, which saw Widzew transformed from rural village to a [[quarter (country subdivision)|quarter]] of Łódź.<ref name=lodzapgov/> [[File:Ul. Niciarniana w Łodzi - widok z parku 01.jpg|thumb|Heinzel & Kunitzer factory, Łódź-Widzew (2011)]] Kunitzer was also involved in setting up an [[electric railway]] (the Koleje Elektryczne Łódzke S.A. and Łódzkie Wąskotorowe Elektryczne Koleje Dojazdowe S.A. stock companies) and in coal import company (Konsorcjum Węglowe "Kunitzer et Co.").<ref name=lodzapgov/> He was a member of the board of many organizations (such as the [[Bank Handlowy]]).<ref name=lodzapgov/> He also had investments outside Polish territories, for example in Russia, where he was involved in the iron mining and steelworking.<ref name=lodzapgov/> He was also involved in philanthropy, and presided for many years over the Łódzkie Chrześcijańskie Towarzystwo Dobroczynności (Łódź Christian Society of Goodwill).<ref name=lodzapgov/>
He was hated by the workers in Łódż, due to his particularly vicious treatment of employees in his factories, and due to fact that he remained in close contact and cooperated with Russian authorities<ref>Niepodległość, Volume 17, Instytut Badania Najnowszej Historji Polski (Warsaw, Poland), Instytut Józefa Piłsudskiego Poświęcony Badaniu Najnowszej Historii Polski (London, England), page 185,Pilsudski Institute of America, 1938</ref> Kunitzer often denied his workers their salaries in order to "teach them reason" which threatened them with hunger; such threat was also used to break down strike at his factory.<ref>Bolesław Leśmian, ''Recepta na miliony'', Książka i Wiedza, 1967, page 101</ref> Workers in his factory faced financial fines and payments<ref>''Miasta polskie w tysiącleciu'', Zakład Narodowy im. Ossolińskich, 1965, Tom 2, page 23</ref> In 1886 report by Russian authorities pointed out that Kunitzer's factory which employed 860 workers, had no first aid room where a doctor could help or examine an injured worker.<ref>''Rocznik łódzki'', 1977, Volume 22, Polskie Towarzystwo Historyczne. Oddział Łódzki Państwowe Wydawnictwo Naukowe, page 121</ref> Kunitzer's factories were also among two with lowest wages in Łódż and there was already a failed attempt to assassinate him in 1893.<ref>{{cite book|author=Paweł Samuś|title="Bunt łódzki" 1892 roku: studia z dziejów wielkiego konfliktu społecznego|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wi_tAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|year=1993|publisher=Wydawn. Uniw. Lódzkiego|isbn=978-83-7016-733-2|pages=64–65}}</ref> Kunitzer himself consequently acted against workers.<ref>{{cite book|author=Paweł Samuś|title="Bunt łódzki" 1892 roku: studia z dziejów wielkiego konfliktu społecznego|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wi_tAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=28 May 2011|year=1993|publisher=Wydawn. Uniw. Lódzkiego|isbn=978-83-7016-733-2|page=64}}</ref>
[[File:Juliusz Kunitzer grob.JPG|thumb|180px|Kunitzer's mausoleum at the Old Cemetery of Łódź]] On 30 September 1905 he was assassinated by [[Polish Socialist Party]] activists in the aftermath of the [[Łódź insurrection (1905)|1905 Łódź insurrection]] in which he refused any concessions to the workers.<ref name=lodzapgov/><ref>Stefan Pytlas, 1994, ''Łódzka burżuazja przemysłowa w latach 1864–1914'', Wydawnictwo Uniwersytetu Łódzkiego, page 212</ref> One of the assailants (Adolf Szulc) was captured; the second one escaped.<ref name=lodzapgov/> The assailant confessed that hundreds of poverty stricken workers who were victims of Kunitzer were his motivation for the attack.<ref>Wacław Pawlak, ''Na łódzkim bruku, 1901–1918'', 1986, Wydawnictwo Lódzkie, page 68</ref> His assassination became the topic of the day for Polish and Russian newspapers; the event was condemned by conservative media, and praised by the radical, socialist ones.<ref name=dl/> His funeral on 3 October that year gathered thousands of people.<ref name=dl/> He was buried at the [[Stary Cmentarz]] at Ogrodowa street, and his grave was marked by a simple, black tombstone.<ref name=dl/>
In 1906 Heinzel & Kunitzer employed 3,343 workers.<ref>{{cite book|url=|title=Deutsche Geschichte im Osten Europas: Land der grossen Ströme|first1= Joachim |last1=Rogall |publisher=Siedler|year=1996|isbn=3-88680-204-3|page=313|language=German}}</ref> The Widzew enterprise was bought by Heinzel and Italians Tanfani and Farinola.<ref name=lodzapgov/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

[[File:ErnstA Bottcher.jpg|thumb|230px|Advertisement Ernst A. Bottcher]] [[Natural history]] specimen dealers had an important role in the development of science in the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries. They supplied the rapidly growing, both in size and number, museums and educational establishments and private collectors whose collections, either in entirety or parts finally entered [[List of natural history museums|museums]]. Most sold not just [[Zoological specimen|zoological]], [[Botany|botanical]] and [[Geology|geological]] specimens but also equipment and books. Many also sold [[Archaeology|archaeological]] and [[Ethnography|ethnographic]] items.They purchased specimens from professional and amateur collectors, sometimes collected themselves as well as acting as agents for the sale of collections. Many were based in [[Mercantilism|mercantile]] centres notably [[Amsterdam]], [[Hamburg]], and [[London]] or in major cities. Some were specialists and some were [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomic]] authorities who wrote scientific works and manuals, some functioned as trading museums or institutes.
This is a list of natural history dealers from the 16th to the 19th century: here are names that are frequently encountered in museum collections.
*[[Johan Hans Abegg]] ([[floruit|fl.]] 1882-1885) Mineral collector and dealer in Zurich. *[[Augustus Theodore Abel]] (?1802-1882); German Mineral dealer resident in [[Ballarat]]. *[[Anton Franz Abraham]] Preparator and dealer in educational materials at " "Naturhistorisches Institut" on Beatrixgasse, Vienna, 1896, on Ungargasse, Vienna in 1903-1906.Supplied specimens to [[Archduke Franz Ferdinand]]. *[[Ludwig Anker]] (1822, Budapest -1887) Insektenhändler *[[Mary Anning]] *[[Bernardino Astfäller]] (1879–1964) Insektenhändler in [[Meran]] *[[Andreas Bang-Haas]] *[[Otto Bang-Haas]] *[[Max Bartel]] (1879–1914) Berlin *[[Leopold and Rudolf Blaschka]] *[[Julius Böhm]] (c. 1850?-1925) Vienna mineral dealers as "Österr.-ungar. Mineralien-Comptoir" or Austro-Hungarian Mineral Dealership. *[[E. P. Bottley|Edward Percy Bottley]] Gregory, Bottley & Lloyd geology and mineral dealership *[[Ernst August Böttcher]], born 14 June 1870 Naturalien und Lehrmittel-Anstalt Berlin C. 2, Brüderstrasse 15. *[[August Friedrich Böttcher]] *[[Brazenor Bros]] Dealers in zoological specimens in [[Brighton]] from 1858-1937. *[[Nérée Boubée]] Paris *[[Adolphe Boucard]] *[[Braun; Karl Friedrich Wilhelm]] (1800–1864) Fossil and mineral dealer in [[Regensburg]] [[:de:Karl Friedrich Wilhelm Braun]] *[[Robert Brendel|Brendel and Sohn]] Botanical modelmakers in Breslau and Berlin. *[[Jean Baptiste Lucien Buquet]] (Paris) *[[Emile Clement]] Australia *[[Giuseppe De Cristoforis]] (Milan) *[[Eduard Dämle]] Insect dealer in Hamburg. *[[Robert Damon]] Natural history dealer in [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]] *[[Émile Deyrolle]] (1838–1917) French naturalist and natural history dealer in Paris. The business was originally owned by his naturalist grandfather, Jean-Baptiste Deyrolle who opened his shop in 1831 at 23, Rue de la Monnaie. Émile’s father [[Achille Deyrolle]] ran the business for many years. It is now at 46, rue du Bac, Paris *[[Henri Donckier de Donceel]] Paris insect dealer *[[Alfred William Ecutt]] (1879-) Newport, Wales. *[[Heinrich E. M. Schulz|Entomologisch Institut Hamburg]] (E. M. Schulz) Hamburg 22, Hamburgerstrasse 45. *[[Josef Erber(naturalist)|Josef Erber]](c. 1830 – c. 1918) Mineral and natural history dealer in Vienna St. Ullrich, Siebensterngasse No. 29. *[[Anton Hermann Fassl]] Naturhistorisches-Institut, 948 Zeidlerstrasse, Teplitz, Bohemia, Germany (now the Czech Republic) *[[Adolarius Jacob Forster]] (1739-1806).Leading mineral dealer of the 18th century with premises in London, Paris and St. Petersburg. *[[R. Godeffroy]] The Godeffroy Museum and dealership. *[[Richard Haensch]] Berlin *[[Johann Wilhelm Adolf Hansemann]] (1784–1862) German insect dealer *[[Thomas Hawkins (geologist)|Thomas Hawkins]] [[File:SchoolMineralogyCollectionFull.JPG|thumb|230px|Mineral collection for schools.Germany.]] *[[John Henry Heuland|Henry Heuland]] (1778-1856) London Mineral collector and dealer *[[Alexander Heyne]] Berlin *[[George Humphrey (naturalist)|George Humphrey]] London dealer in shells and ‘curiosities’ in the 18th century. *[[Charles Jamrach]] *[[Charles Georges Javet]] *[[Edward Wesley Janson]] London *[[E. Active 1900- 1930s? *[[Friedrich Kohl]] (1839–1907) Fossil and mineral dealer [[File:BLW Skeleton of a common mole.jpg|thumb|230px|Mole skeleton supplied by T Gerrard & Co Ltd.]] *[[Adam August Krantz]] (1809–1872); Natural history dealer in Berlin after 1850 in Bonn. *[[Frank H. Lattin & Co.]] [[Albion (town), Orleans County, New York|Albion]], New York *[[Benjamin Leadbeater]] (1760–1837) Dealer in ornithological specimens. *[[Charles Johnson Maynard]] (1845-1929) Natural history dealer in Boston and Newton, Massachusetts. *[[Friedrich Christian Meuschen]] *[[Heinrich Benno Möschler]] *[[Eugène Le Moult]] *[[Ida Laura Pfeiffer]] *[[Louis Thomas Jérôme Auzoux|Maison Azoux]] *[[Maison Tramond]] Established by the mid-19th century at 9 Rue de l' Ecole de Medicine in Paris.Later "Maison Tramond - N. Butterfly dealer in [[Florence]], Italy - collected extensively in Spain and Portugal also Cuba. Supplied butterflies to [[Ruggero Verity|Roger Verity]] and European butterflies to R.C. Williams, Academy of Natural Sciences, Philadelphia. *[[Lovell Augustus Reeve]] [[File:Field fg03.jpg|thumb|230px|The Field Museum in Chicago. Late entrants United States museums were major purchasers.]] *[[Edmund Reitter]] "Natural History Institute" 1879 -1880 [[Vienna]], 1881-1891 [[Mödling]], after 1891 [[Paskov|Paskau]] and [[Munich]] (extant). *[[Carl Ribbe]] *[[Heinrich Ribbe]] (1832–1898) Entomologist and dealer in Berlin *[[Hermann Rolle]] Berlin *[[William Frederick Henry Rosenberg]] (1868–1957) 57 Haverstock Hill, London [[Floruit|fl.]] 1920s. Claimed to hold 5,000 bird species as scientific skins (and to be the largest bird skin dealership in the world). Supplier to museums and private collectors. Traveller. *[[Emil Adolf Rossmässler]] Natural History dealer *[[Karl Rost]] *[[Fritz Rühl]] *[[Auguste Sallé]] *[[Christian Julius Wilhelm Schiede]] *[[Wilhelm Schlüter]] *[[Gustav Schneider]] (1867–1958) Basel *[[Gustav Schrader]] *[[Wilhelm Schlüter]] *[[Southwick & Jencks’ Natural History Store]] Providence, Rhode Island *[[Otto Staudinger]] *[[Stazione Zoologica|Stazione Zoologica Anton Dohrn]] Marine specimens. *[[Wilh. Steeg]] "Dr. Steeg & Reuter" after 1879. Crystallographic microscope slides. *[[Alexandre Stuer]](fl. 1890s-1920?) Paris mineral dealer. Owner of Comptoir Géologique et Minéralogique, 40, rue de Mathurins and at 4, rue de Castellane. *[[John Crace Stevens]] Covent Gardens auctioneer. *[[Emanuel Sweerts]] (1552–1612) Dutch merchant and natural history dealer. [[File:Necropsar leguati.jpg|thumb|230px|The [[grey trembler]]. In 1898 a unique skin was discovered in the Liverpool Museum. This specimen was obtained by Edward Smith-Stanley, 13th Earl of Derby from bird collector Jules Verreaux in 1850. It was labeled only "Madagascar"]] *[[Rudolf Tancré]] (1842–1934) [[Anklam]], Pomerania Dealer in Lepidoptera mainly of Central Asia and Siberia. *[[Georg Thorey]] - Hamburg pharmacist and beetle collector. Also sold beetles to other natural history collectors.<ref>Lynn K. Nyhart "Civic and economic zoology in nineteenth-century Germany: The "Living communities"of Karl Mobius" Isis 4 (1998)pp. 605-630</ref> *[[Johann Gustav Friedrich Umlauff]] (1833–1889) Proprietor of prominent Hamburg-based natural history and ethnographic dealership and associated museum. *[[Unio Itineraria]] a German Scientific Society based in Esslingen am Neckar sold specimens as a dealership. *[[Van Ingen & Van Ingen]] *[[Jules Verreaux]] Owner of Maison Verreaux, established in 1803 by his father, Jacques Philippe Verreaux, at Place des Vosges in Paris, which was the earliest known company that dealt with objects of natural history. *[[Jean Villet]] Cape Town *[[Voigt & Hochgesang]] Göttingen *[[Józef Warszewicz]] Guatemala 1844-1850 *[[Henry Augustus Ward]] Founder of Ward's Natural History Establishment in Rochester, New York. *[[Rowland Ward]] London *[[White Watson]] *[[William Watkins (entomologist)|William Watkins]] Began trading in 1874 in [[Eastbourne]]. In 1879 the address was 36 [[Strand, London|The Strand]], London. In 1907 the dealership became Watkins & Doncaster (1907). In 1937 ownership passed to Frederick Metté an expert on bird eggs. *[[Frank Blake Webster]]'s Naturalists Supply Depot 409 Washington Street, Hyde Park, Massachusetts *[[Walter Freeman Webb]] (1869–1957) Shell dealer St. Petersburg, Florida *[[Bryce McMurdo Wright]] father (1814-1875) or son (1850-1895), both with same name and both dealers at 90 Great Russell Street, London. They dealt in minerals and fossils, ethnographic and archaeological objects. *[[Bohuslav Železný]] Prague 1890-? Lepidoptera. *[[Emil Weiske]] Saalfeld Insect and bird collector and dealer. *[[Rudolf Zimmermann]] (1878–1943) mineralogist and dealer in natural history specimens for schools based in Chemnitz, Saxony. Author of ''Die Mineralien. Eine Anleitung zum Sammeln und Bestimmen derselben nebst einer Beschreibung der wichtigsten Arten''

'''Lucien Barrière''' (14 January 1923 – 17 September 1990) was a French entrepreneur and [[businessman]]. He was the heir and founder of the [[Lucien Barrière group]], one of the largest group of casinos, luxury hotels, resorts and restaurants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.challenges.fr/entreprise/20130606.CHA0316/bluffant-dominique-desseigne-pdg-de-groupe-lucien-barriere.html|title=Bluffant - Dominique Desseigne, PDG de Groupe Lucien Barrière|work=Challenges|date=June 7, 2013|language=fr}}</ref>
==Biography==
He was born in the French Ardèche region from a modest, goat raising family.
In 1962, he was chosen by his uncle François André, who had no direct descendants, to succeed him as head of several successful companies specializing in the operation of [[casino]]s and luxury hotels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abcbourse.com/apprendre/biographie_lucien_barriere-98|title=Lucien Barriere|work=ABC Bourse|date=|language=fr}}</ref> The casinos of [[Deauville]], [[Cannes]] and [[La Baule]] and the hotels Normandy Barriere, Royal Barriere and the Hotel du Golf Barriere de Deauville were among the best known assets of the company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.normandie-tourisme.fr/Hotel-du-Golf-Barriere/HOT/SAINT-ARNOULT/fiche-HOTNOR014FS001S9-2.html|title=Hotel du Golf Barrière|work=Normandy Tourism|date=}}</ref>
In 1959, he became the general manager of the group. For thirty years he developed the successful Barriere empire following the same policy as his predecessor: luxury, sophistication, perfection, elegance, refinement, friendliness and cultivating the French [[joie de vivre]].
He married Martha Szentgyörgyi (died October 11, 2008), a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] dancer. Martha had a daughter from a previous marriage, Diane, born in 1957, which he adopted and raised as his own. He taught her the know-how of the trade, before designating her as the sole heir of his luxury empire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parismatch.com/Actu/Economie/Dominique-Desseigne-se-devoile-pour-Paris-Match-et-parle-de-ses-relations-avec-Rachida-Dati-136419|title=Dominique Desseigne se dévoile pour PAris Match et parle de ses relations avec Rachida Dati|work=Paris Match|date=October 2, 2012|language=fr}}</ref>
In 1962, he founded the [[Lucien Barrière group]], one of the first French companies charged with managing casinos and luxury hotels.
In 1975, Lucien Barrière sponsored the creation of the [[American Film Festival]] in Deauville, alongside the major proponents of this idea, the Mayor of Deauville [[Michel d'Ornano]], André Halimi and Lionel Shushan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.confidentielles.com/r_13496_le-parcours-de-lucien-barriere.htm|title=Le parcours de Lucien Barrière|work=Confidentielles|date=|language=fr}}</ref>
In 1990, he died at Caen University Hospital of cardiac arrest at the age of 67, following complications resulting from a [[coronary angioplasty]] carried out by Professor Grollier. Diane, married to the notary Dominique Desseigne, succeeded her adoptive father as head of the group and pursued the same successful policy as her predecessors. In July 1995 she was the victim of a serious plane crash that left her [[quadriplegic]], and later died in May 2001 at 44 years<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hellocoton.fr/to/PaP#http://www.purepeople.com/article/mort-de-martha-barriere-du-groupe-barriere_a17126/1|title=Mort de MArtha Barrière, du groupe Barrière...|work=Pure People|date=|language=fr}}</ref>{{,}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.labandearuquier.com/Hommage-a-Martha-Barriere-l-amie.html|title=Hommage à Martha Barrière, l'ami de Steevy|work=La bande à Ruquier|date=|language=fr}}</ref>

The '''Ohlson O-Score for predicting bankruptcy''' is a multi-factor financial formula postulated in 1980 by Dr. [[James Ohlson]] of the [[New York University]] Stern Accounting Department as an alternative to the [[Altman Z-score]] for predicting financial distress.<ref name="ycharts">{{cite web|url=http://ycharts.com/glossary/terms/ohlson_score|title=Ohlson's O-Score Definition|website=ycharts.com|accessdate=2014-06-12}}</ref>
==Calculation of the O-Score== The Ohlson O-Score is the result of a 9-factor linear combination of [[coefficient]]-weighted business ratios which are readily obtained or derived from the standard periodic financial disclosure statements provided by publicly traded corporations. Two of the factors utilized are widely considered to be dummies as their value and thus their impact upon the formula typically is 0.<ref name="stockopedia">{{cite web|url=http://www.stockopedia.com/content/improving-on-the-altman-z-score-part-2-the-ohlson-o-score-70800/|title=Improving On The Altman Z-Score, Part 2: The Ohlson O-Score | first = Jonathan | last = Stokes | date = 13 February 2013 | website=stockopedia.com|accessdate=2014-06-12}}</ref> When using an O-Score to evaluate the probability of company’s failure, then exp(O-Score) is divided by 1 + exp(O-score).<ref name="fdic">{{cite web|url=http://www.fdic.gov/bank/analytical/cfr/2008/jan/CFR_SS_2008_KarlynMitchell.pdf|date=7 January 2008|title=Bankers on Boards, Financial Constraints, and Financial Distress (''Preliminary and incomplete. Please do not quote.'')| first1 = Karlyn | last1 = Mitchell | first2 = Mark D. | last2 = Walker|accessdate=2014-06-12}}</ref>
The calculation for Ohlson’s O-Score appears below:<ref name="JStor">{{cite web|url=http://teaching.ust.hk/~ismt551/project2/Ohlson.pdf|title=Financial Ratios and the Probabilistic Prediction of Bankruptcy|author=James A. Ohlson|accessdate=2014-08-13}}</ref>
: <math> \begin{align} T = {} & -1.32 - 0.407\log(TA_t/GNP) + 6.03\frac{TL_t}{TA_t} - 1.43\frac{WC_t}{TA_t} + 0.0757\frac{CL_t}{CA_t} \\[10pt] & {} - 1.72 X - 2.37\frac{NI_t}{TA_t} - 1.83\frac{FFO_t}{TL_t} + 0.285Y - 0.521\frac{NI_t-NI_{t-1}}{|NI_t| + |NI_{t-1}|} \end{align} </math>
where
* ''TA'' = [[total assets]] * ''GNP'' = [[Gross National Product price index level]] * ''TL'' = [[total liabilities]] * ''WC'' = [[working capital]] * ''CL'' = current liabilities * ''CA'' = [[current assets]] * ''X'' = 1 if ''TL'' > ''TA'', 0 otherwise * ''NI'' = [[net income]] * ''FFO'' = funds from operations * ''Y'' = 1 if a [[net loss]] for the last two years, 0 otherwise
==Interpretation==
The original model for the O-Score was derived from the study of a pool of just over 2000 companies, whereas by comparison its predecessor the Altman Z-Score considered just 66 companies. As a result, the O-Score is significantly more accurate a predictor of bankruptcy within a 2-year period. The original Z-Score was estimated to be over 70% accurate with its later variants reaching as high as 90% accuracy. The O-Score is more accurate than this.
However, no mathematical model is 100% accurate, so while the O-Score may forecast bankruptcy or solvency, factors both inside and outside of the formula can impact its accuracy. Furthermore, later [[bankruptcy prediction]] models such as the hazard based model proposed by Campbell, Hilscher, and Szilagyi in 2011<ref name="citeseerx">{{cite paper | citeseerx = 10.1.1.233.2093 | title = Predicting financial distress and the performance of distressed stocks | first1 = John Y. | last1 = Campbell | first2 = Jens | last2 = Hilscher | first3 = Jan | last3 = Szilagyi }}</ref> have proven more accurate still. For the O-Score, any results larger than 0.5 suggests that the firm will default within two years.

{{Orphan|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox writer | name = Pedro De Abreu | image = Pedro De Abreu in Dubai.jpg | image_size = 220px | caption = De Abreu at a book signing in Dubai | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1989|07|14}} | birth_place = [[Brasília]], [[Federal District (Brazil)|DF]], Brazil | nationality = [[Brazilian people|Brazilian]]
[[American people|American]] | occupation = Entrepreuner • educator • author | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]]
[[University of South Carolina]] | website = {{URL|http://pedrodeabreu.com}} | awards = {{unbulleted list| Harvard University Leadership in Education Award | Coca-Cola New Century Scholar | All-SC Academic Team | Darla Moore Emerging Leader | Fulbright Fellowship Finalist| Walker Institute Scholar | Magellan Scholar}} }} '''Pedro de Abreu''' (born July 14, 1989) is a [[Brazilian American]] entrepreneur, educator, and author. He was the co-founder of a multi-media company in Hollywood, California, and the founder and director of the [[nonprofit organization]] Check Mate Foundation.{{cite web |url= http://www.wltx.com/news/article/138076/2/Math-Science-English-and-Chess- |title=Math, Science, English, and Chess? |publisher= wltx.com |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2012-03-04}}http://www.moore.sc.edu/news.aspx?article_id=326 De Abreu directs the Brain and Cognitive Science thematic at the AI Initiative. http://ai-initiative.org/applications/brain-cognitive-science/ De Abreu was published in a book by [[Marshall Cavendish]], a subsidiary company to the [[Times Publishing Company|Times Publishing Group]], among 25 young entrepreneurs from around the world.{{cite web | url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Young-Entrepreneur-World-Teen-trepreneurs-Scratching/dp/9814361097 | title=Young Entrepreneur World: How 25 Teen-trepreneurs Succeeded and Left World Leaders Scratching Their Heads [Paperback] | accessdate=2012-07-21}}http://www.tedxcolumbiasc.com/pedro-de-abreu/ ==Early life and education== De Abreu was born in [[Brasília]], [[Federal District (Brazil)|Distrito Federal]], and grew up on the coastal city of [[João Pessoa, Paraíba|João Pessoa]], [[Paraíba]], where he experienced poverty and struggled to get by as a teenager.http://gandbmagazine.com/mag/portraits He moved to America in 2005 without knowing how to speak English. He became fluent in one year and was placed into [[Advanced Placement]] classes, including English, European history and psychology.{{cite web |url= http://www.midlandsbiz.com/articles/8104/ |title=Pedro De Abreu, Recent Midlands Tech Graduate, Spoke to St. Andrews Rotary Club |publisher=midlandsbiz.com |date=2011-06-04 |accessdate=2012-03-04}} He graduated from Chapin High School and [[Midlands Technical College]] before attending the [[Moore School of Business]] at the [[University of South Carolina]], focusing his work on [[economics]]. De Abreu subsequently attended [[Harvard University]], where he attained a master's degree in an emerging [[science|scientific]] field that brings together [[cognitive neuroscience]], [[developmental cognitive neuroscience]], [[educational psychology]], [[education theory]] and other related disciplines to explore the interactions between biological processes and practice.{{cite journal | last1 = Ansari | first1 = D | authorlink1 = | last2 = Coch | first2 = D | year = 2006 | title = Bridges over troubled waters: Education and cognitive neuroscience | journal = Trends in Cognitive Sciences | volume = 10 | issue = 4 | pages = 146–151 | publisher = Elsevier Science | doi = 10.1016/j.tics.2006.02.007 | pmid = 16530462}}{{cite journal | last1 = Coch | first1 = D | authorlink1 = | last2 = Ansari | first2 = D | year = 2008 | title = Thinking about mechanisms is crucial to connecting neuroscience and education | journal = Cortex | volume = 45 | issue = 4 | pages = 546–547 | publisher = Elsevier Science | doi = 10.1016/j.cortex.2008.06.001 | pmid = 18649878}} ==Awards== At Harvard, De Abreu received the prestigious Leadership in Education Award, a merit-based fellowship given to top master's degree candidates with strong leadership potential.http://www.gse.harvard.edu/admissions/financial_aid/fellowships/meritbased.html#ixzz2zP1Ojqrshttp://midlandsbiz.whosonthemove.com/pressreleases/darla-moore-school-business-graduate-pedro-de-abreu-finalist-2016-forbes-30-30/http://www.prlog.org/12523651-pedro-de-abreu-14x-innovation-group-ceo-finalist-in-the-2016-forbes-30-under-30-list.html De Abreu is South Carolina's New Century Scholar, an award given by [[Phi Theta Kappa]], [[USA Today]] and the [[Coca-Cola Foundation]] to the state's top student.http://www.ptk.org/schol/recipients/2011/newcentury.php{{cite web|url=http://www.ccjournal-digital.com/ccjournal/20110405online?pg=72#pg72 |title=Community College Journal - April/May 2011 |publisher=Ccjournal-digital.com |date=2011-03-29 |accessdate=2012-03-04}}{{cite web|url=http://www.communitycollegetimes.com/Pages/Funding/2011-Coca-Cola-scholars.aspx |title=2011 New Century Scholars |publisher=Communitycollegetimes.com |date=2011-05-04 |accessdate=2012-03-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314062317/http://www.communitycollegetimes.com/Pages/Funding/2011-Coca-Cola-scholars.aspx |archivedate=March 14, 2012 }} De Abreu is a Walker Institute and Magellan Scholar, City of Columbia Fellow, and the recipient of the C. Russell Hill Memorial Scholarship for Economics.http://www.midlandsbiz.com/articles/11534/ The latter for his research titled "The Development of Empathy, Leadership and Pro-Social Dispositions in Middle-School and High School Age Children: A Case Study of Peer Education and the Anne Frank Story in Brazil." http://www.ed.sc.edu/News.asp?article=1092{{cite web|url=http://www.sc.edu/provost/leadership/program/index.shtml |title=Leadership - Office of the Provost |publisher=Sc.edu |date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2012-03-04}}{{cite web|url=http://mooreschool.sc.edu/news.aspx?article_id=278 |title=News | The Moore School of Business | University of South Carolina |publisher=Mooreschool.sc.edu |date=2011-10-21 |accessdate=2012-03-04}} ==Government== In April 2014, De Abreu was appointed to serve on the board of directors of the Central Midlands Council of Governments(CMCOG), one of the most influential councils in [[South Carolina]], assisting local governments develop local and regional plans within four midlands counties ([[Fairfield County, South Carolina|Fairfield]], [[Lexington County, South Carolina|Lexington]], [[Newberry]], [[Richland County, South Carolina|Richland]]), as well as providing local governments with planning and technical support to improve the quality of life within the regions. CMCOG currently consists of 14 member governments in its board of directors, and serves in excess of 725,000 people. http://centralmidlands.org/about-us/board-members.htmlhttp://centralmidlands.org/wp-content/uploads/6.26.14_Board-Meeting-Agenda-Packet.o.pdfhttp://www.richlandonline.com/Portals/0/Departments/CountyCouncil/Minutes/Reg%2004-15-14.pdf ==Social Entrepreneur== ===Nonprofit=== In [[South Carolina]], De Abreu started the non-profit Check Mate Foundation, which focuses on teaching [[chess]] and leadership to children with disabilities and also to [[underprivileged children]]. In an interview in 2011, he said: "Chess is just really a medium through which we try to implement leadership and character... Chess will never be on the SAT. But the patience, analytical skills, the thinking skills, the ability to do those things will be skills that will be forever in demand."http://www.wltx.com/news/story.aspx?storyid=138076 In another interview, he stated: "Studies have shown that chess develops logical thinking, improves concentration and promotes imagination, creativity and independence."http://www.sc.edu/news/newsarticle.php?nid=2069#.UbLpokCTi90 As a speaker, De Abreu was represented internationally by [[Sabirul Islam]]'s Teen Speakers International Bureau.{{cite web|url=http://www.teen-speakers.com/?p=251 |title=Pedro De Abreu |publisher=Teen-speakers.com |date=2011-10-11 |accessdate=2012-03-04}}[[File:De Abreu at TEDxColumbiaSC.jpg|thumb|De Abreu at TEDx]]De Abreu has spoken in countries like [[Dubai]], [[Oman]], [[Kuwait]], [[Bahrain]] and [[Brazil]], and at [[TEDx]].http://leanblitz.net/2013/01/a-visit-to-tedxcolumbiasc/http://www.sc.edu/news/newsarticle.php?nid=5271#.UbLum0CTi90https://www.ted.com/tedx/events/6478https://www.facebook.com/tedxyouthcolumbiasc/photos/pb.337793959590789.-2207520000.1397975724./676295039074011/?type=3&theater ====Author==== In 2011, De Abreu published his first book, detailing the hardshipshttp://theindiechicks.com/spotlights/from-hardship-to-stages-around-the-world-pedro-de-abreu/ he had to overcome in [[Brazil]] due to the lack of opportunity, and in [[United States of America|America]] for not being able to speak English on his arrival, as well as practical steps one can take to achieve meaningful change. Author Scott Simson said that his book is "a must read for anyone wanting to advance their life."https://www.amazon.com/The-ABC-SUCCESS-Series-ebook/dp/B006Z06WTM De Abreu writes a monthly column for [[Richard Branson]]'s [[Virgin Group|Virgin]] on the topics of science, innovation, entrepreneurship, and public speaking.http://www.virgin.com/author/pedro-de-abreu In 2012, De Abreu was featured on Young Entrepreneur World: How 25 Teen-Trepreneurs Succeeded and Left World Leaders Scratching Their Heads, published by British publisher [[Marshall Cavendish]], a [[subsidiary company]] of [[Times Publishing Group]], the printing and publishing subsidiary of [[Singapore]]-based conglomerate [[Fraser and Neave]]. '''Academia''' De Abreu is a Teaching Fellow at the [[Harvard Graduate School of Education]].https://canvas.harvard.edu/courses/8690/pages/syllabus He facilitates the Management Development Program at the [[Harvard Graduate School of Education]] and the Mind, Brain, Behavior Interfaculty Thesis Workshops for graduating seniors at Harvard College. De Abreu is the Director of the Artificial Intelligence, Brain, and Cognitive Sciences thematic at the [[AI Initiative]].http://www.scetv.org/blog/carolina-money/2016/qa-conversation-usc-and-harvard-alumnus-pedro-de-abreu-finalist-2016-forbes ==Television== De Abreu hosted a biweekly segment on [[WLTX]], a [[CBS]]-affiliated television station, called The Motivational Minute, on motivation and leadership.http://www.wltx.com/video/2615784684001/1/Your-Motivational-Minute-with-Pedro-de-Abreuhttp://midlandsbiz.com/articles/15176/ ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite web |url=http://www.sctechsystem.com/news/ptk2011.html |title=SC Technical College System honors Phi Theta Kappa All-State Academic Team Members |work=sctechsystem.com |publisher=SC State Board for Technical and Comprehensive Education |accessdate=Nov 20, 2011}} * {{cite book |last=Islam |first=Sabirul |title=Young Entrepreneur World: How 25 Teen-Trepreneurs Succeeded and Left World Leaders Scratching Their Heads |publisher=[[Marshall Cavendish]] |date=15 February 2012 |isbn=978-981-4361-09-5}} ==External links== * {{Official website|pedrodeabreu.com/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abreu, Pedro de}} [[Category:1989 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Brasília]] [[Category:Brazilian businesspeople]] [[Category:Brazilian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:American motivational speakers]] [[Category:University of South Carolina alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Graduate School of Education alumni]]
